Decisions will have to be made at certain points in the
story. You can select one of the options displayed
on-screen, affecting your Karma or Affinity to the target
character depending on the choices you make.

A value showing the player’s dispositional tendencies that
changes with your decisions. You can check your current
status on the Profile screen in the menu. There are three
types of Karma: Harmonious, Wrathful, and Moral. This value
will change how the story unfolds.
Karma will affect Agumon’s evolution.

A value showing your intimacy with other characters that
changes with your decisions. You can check your current
status on the Profile screen in the menu. Affinity affects
the evolution of other characters and monsters, the
frequency of Battle Backup occurring in battles, and more.

Special destinations for partner monsters of characters
with a certain level of Affinity will be added to the Map
after specific chapters. Moving to one of these
destinations will trigger an evolution event, unlocking
a new evolution for that character.

A situation called Free Action can occur during the story.
Free Action has limited moves, and acts mainly to raise
Affinity with other characters.

You have a limited number of moves during Free Action.
This limit is displayed at the top-right of the Map screen
(remaining moves/total moves). When you run out of moves,
you must speak to the character whose Affinity you want to
raise.

Moves are consumed by talking with characters, or by
triggering some events. Conversations and events that
consume moves have a <sprite index=4> displayed on the map list or
focused target.

Entering spots on the map with a <sprite index=1> mark will trigger
a Free Battle. These are opportunities to gain experience
and items, and you can persuade enemies into becoming
allies through conversation. You can take these on as many
times as you want, making them an excellent option for
bolstering your battle strength.

A situation known as Exploration can occur during the
story. In Exploration, you can choose where to move on the
map, talk with characters, and investigate, all to obtain
items and find clues to advance the plot.

In Exploration, move the cursor to start a conversation or
investigate things. You can focus directly on targets. For
important events, <sprite index=6> is displayed on the focused target.
During Exploration you can also focus on areas other than characters. Investigate such places and you may discover hidden items.

During Exploration, you can switch to Camera Mode.
Distortion may appear on the screen during this mode,
progressing the story or letting you obtain items by
investigating it. The camera icon is displayed in the
upper-left corner for important events.

You may encounter enemies whenever you investigate
distortion in Camera Mode. For these battles, you have the
options to fight or avoid them altogether. You also have
the option to persuade foes through conversation.

You can open the Pause Menu during the story or on the Map
screen. From the Pause Menu, you can access Stats, Profiles,
Items, Field Guide, Help, Settings and Data functions.

During Free Action or Exploration, you can select any
points on the map to advance the story. Places you can go
change with story progression. Info on each location is
displayed in the lower-right part of the Map screen.

Important events will occur in places marked with <sprite index=0> or <sprite index=2>
on the map list as the story progresses. <sprite index=0> will trigger
when you move to that location, and <sprite index=2> will trigger events
when you talk with characters in that location.

<sprite index=3> shows the characters in that location. You can check
what characters are where in the information in the lower
part of the Map screen. <sprite index=1> shows places where Free Battles
will occur. <sprite index=4> consumes moves during Free Action.

Victory and defeat conditions are displayed at the start
of battle. You can check victory conditions at any time
during battle from the Battle Menu. Victory conditions are
displayed in the Battle Menu.

You can select a difficulty at the start of battle. There
are three difficulties: Easy, Normal and Hard. Battles are
usually set to Normal difficulty.

You can switch to the free cursor when selecting a command
in battle, letting you move freely around the battle map.
You can also rotate the camera and adjust the camera
distance.

In addition to basic stats like HP, SP and Attribute, each
unit has various abilities such as speed and mobility, and
resistances. You can check individual stats on the Stats
page for each unit.

Each unit has their own Passive Skills, unique abilities
that remain active during the entire battle. You can check
these abilities on the Stats page for each unit.

During battle, unit turn order is determined by the Speed
of enemy and ally units. Status abnormalities and buffs
that alter Speed will change the turn order.

During battle, selecting the Move command during a unit’s
turn causes a cursor to appear. Select a point within the
blue grid (your movement range) to move. After moving, you
can cancel back to your original position before you take
any action.

Each unit has their own ability to climb (and descend)
differences in elevation. During battle, they cannot climb
or descend an elevation that exceeds this ability. Hover
the cursor over a unit to check their <sprite index=113> Vertical
Movement (VERT MOVE) stat.

During battle, selecting the Attack command during a unit’s
turn displays the Skill List. Select any skill from the
list to use it. This command cannot be used with items in
a single turn.

After you choose a skill and select an attack target,
predictions like damage, accuracy, and counterattack % are
displayed. The higher the counterattack %, the more likely
an enemy is to counter when attacked.

Units have individual resistances to <sprite index=114> Fire, <sprite index=115> Water,
<sprite index=116> Wind, <sprite index=117> Earth, <sprite index=118> Light and <sprite index=119> Dark element skills. The
higher the resistance, the less damage they receive from
a corresponding skill.

The direction from which you attack your opponent will
affect its strength. Side attacks are stronger and more
accurate than frontal attacks, and rear attacks are
stronger and more accurate than side attacks. Also,
attacks from the side or rear are not affected by
a opponent defending.

Attacks from higher elevations increase the chance of
a critical hit. The greater the difference in elevation
between the attacker and the attacked, the greater this
chance becomes.

As you attack, friends may try to back you up. There are
three types of battle backup: Encouragement, Team Attack,
and Support. Battle backup rates change depending on
Takuma’s affinities, as well as unit relationships to each
other on the battle map.

“Encouragement” has a set chance to occur before an
attack, as a friend cheers on the attacking unit and raises
their attack power for that attack only.

“Team Attack” has a set chance to occur after an attack,
and automatically adds an Attack after the attacking
unit. This attack does not use the attacker’s turn. Also,
Team Attacks only occur when a friend is close to the
target of the Team Attack.

“Support” has a set chance to occur after a unit action.
A friend cheers on a unit after their attack, helping them
recover a certain amount of HP and SP.

During battle, selecting the Item command during a unit’s
turn opens the Recovery Item List. Select an item from the
list to use it. Cannot be used with attacks in a single
turn.

During battle, using the Evolve command on a main character
partner unit displays their evolution tree. Evolution
requires a certain amount of SP, in exchange for
dramatically boosting abilities and changing skills.
Remaining HP stays at the same percentage as before the
evolution.

During battle, monsters evolved through the Evolve command
consume a fixed amount of SP each turn in order to maintain
their form, and return to their original (Rookie) form when
SP runs out. You can also return them to their original
form (devolve them) voluntarily.

During battle, the Talk command is only available on the
turns of main character partner units. Subjects of
conversation are divided into enemies and allies, and you
can only talk to enemies in Free Battles or during
encounters while exploring.

During battle, use the Talk command to receive
encouragement from your friends, gaining a variety of
effects. The effects are shown under the list of
conversation subjects. Also, you can only use the Talk
command once per child in battle.

Using the Talk command during battle with enemies lets you
answer their questions from a list of options. Garnering
a certain amount of sympathy from your answers will make
them hear you out. Note that the “Be my friend!” request
may not succeed.

During a battle, select the End Turn command to end the
turn of a unit that has run out of actions you wish to
perform, and move on to the next unit’s action. When ending
a unit’s turn, you can pick the direction that unit will
face.

During battle, units that end a turn without attacking or
using items will automatically take a defensive stance.
Units automatically stop defending in one turn.

During battle, while an ally unit is in Rookie form (and
for all Rookie-level Free Monsters), ending a turn without
attacking or using items will recover 10% of their SP. If
said monster also does not move, they recover 30% of their
SP instead.

During battle, you can open the Battle Menu at any time
except during animations such as movements or attacks. You
can use the following functions from the Battle Menu:
Victory Conditions, Auto, Suspend, Give Up, Retry, Help and
Settings.

Select one of five strategies with different
characteristics, then leave battles to the AI. A summary
of each strategy is shown under the Strategies list. Also,
you can suspend a strategy at any time during auto-battle.

Suspend a battle, save situation data, and return to the
title screen. Suspended battle data is only a temporary
save, and is lost if not used in subsequent play.

You can check the stats of ally monsters with Stats in the
Pause Menu. Organize monsters by individual stats, 
or release any monster.

After choosing any monster on the Pause Menu’s Stats screen,
select Skills from the top tabs to check their skills.
Original or equipped skills are displayed. You can check
each skill’s effect, SP used, range, and effect area.

After choosing any monster on the Pause Menu’s 
Stats screen, select Equipment from the top tabs to 
check their equipment. All monsters have two equipment slots. With Change, choose and equip 
Skill or Enhancement items.

After choosing any monster on the Pause Menu’s 
Stats screen, select Training from the top tabs to 
train them. Select and give training items from the 
list to raise monster stats.

After choosing any monster on the Pause Menu’s 
Stats screen, select Evolution from the top tabs to 
check evolutions. Evolution trees are displayed for 
each monster, letting you check their evolution paths.

On the Pause Menu’s Profile screen, you can check
Takuma’s Karma and Affinity with main characters. 
Selecting a character besides Takuma lets you check
their Battle Backup rate in battle.

After selecting a character from the Pause Menu’s 
Profile screen, you can check character information, 
episodes and partner monster information from the 
top tabs. Episodes are gradually unlocked through 
story progression.

On the Pause Menu’s Items screen, you can check 
items obtained during battles or exploration. Items 
are divided into Recovery Items, Enhancement 
Items, Skill Items, Training Items, and Key Items.

Aside from specific monsters, all units that appear in
battle fall into <sprite index=102> Moral (Vaccine), <sprite index=100> Wrathful (Virus) or <sprite index=101>
Harmonious (Data) types.
Tip: Effect of Defending

During battle, defending reduces frontal attack damage
received by half. Attacks from the side or rear are
unaffected.

Tip: Skill Attributes

The three monster types have a rock-paper-scissors
relationship with each other, boosting attack damage
against weak types and reducing it against strong types.
<sprite index=102> Moral (Vaccine) is strong against <sprite index=100> Wrathful (Virus),
<sprite index=100> Wrathful (Virus) is strong against <sprite index=101> Harmonious (Data),
and <sprite index=101> Harmonious (Data) is strong against <sprite index=102> Moral
(Vaccine).

Units have one of two Move Types: <sprite index=110> Land or <sprite index=111> Air. Air
Move Types can even move over disconnected ground.

Skills are moves unique to each unit, and are classified
as <sprite index=105> Physical Attacks (PHYS ATK) or <sprite index=107> Special Attacks
(SP ATK). Unit stats include <sprite index=106> Physical Defense (PHYS DEF)
and <sprite index=108> Special Defense (SP DEF), affecting the damage received
from skills.

When units use skills, each one consumes a set amount of
SP. Each unit always has the Attack skill, which doesn’t
consume SP.

A skill’s Range is shows the places said skill can target.
Area shows how far a skill’s effect spreads around the
point of impact.

During battle, gaining a status abnormality restricts
a unit somehow, preventing them from moving, using skills
and more. Said monster will recover after a set number of
turns, or by using a Recovery item. Stunned, Frozen and
Confused abnormalities are canceled when the afflicted
unit gets attacked.

<sprite index=120> Stunned, <sprite index=121> Frozen, and <sprite index=123> Paralyzed render a unit unable
to move. <sprite index=122> Poisoned inflicts a set amount of damage
every turn, and <sprite index=124> Sealed prevents a unit from using any
skill besides Attack. <sprite index=125> Confused renders a unit
uncontrollable, causing it to attack itself and its allies.

The Give Up option ends the current battle and returns you
to the game’s title screen. In Free Battles, you return back
to the Map screen. Retry returns you to the start of the
current battle. (Note that all items obtained or consumed
during the battle are reset.)

When evolving a Free Monster, choose a monster on the Main
Menu’s Stats screen, then select an evolution path from
the evolution tree (note that they cannot be devolved).
Evolution also requires specific items.

Use these during battle to restore unit HP and SP. To use
one, select a unit’s Item command to open the list, then
select any item.

Putting equipment on monsters boosts their stats and
bestows special effects. To equip items, choose any monster
from the Stats screen and select Equipment from the top
tabs.

Putting equipment on monsters lets you use that equipment’s
skills in battle. To equip items, choose any monster from
the Stats screen and select Equipment from the top tabs.

Use these on monsters to boost their stats, evolve Free
Monsters, and more. To use them, choose any monster from
the Stats screen and select Training or Evolution from the
top tabs.
Items needed to progress the plot.

Skills are divided into different Skill Attributes:
<sprite index=114> Fire, <sprite index=115> Water, <sprite index=116> Wind, <sprite index=117> Earth, <sprite index=118> Light and <sprite index=119> Dark.
(There are non-elemental skills as well). The color of
the <sprite index=105> or <sprite index=107> icon next to a skill name represents its
attribute.
Tip: Free Monsters

This refers to monsters that aren’t main character
partners. They appear as enemies in Free Battles, or
encounters during exploration. Persuading them with the
Talk command may turn them into allies.
Tip: Stat Tendencies

Among the monsters, All-Rounder types are balanced overall,
while Mobility types are specialized in MOVE AMT and VERT
MOVE. Attack types have high PHYS ATK, Special Attack types
have high SP ATK, and Defense types have high PHYS DEF and
SP DEF.
